content.content: TL;DR Web application for displaying a few relevant statistics about Maker Delegates. The webapp runs at https://delegates.makerlabs.one/.  maker-delegates-overview1960×540 45.6 KB   Context In order to increase transparency around the recently introduced Maker Delegates, the idea of a small webapp was born at short notice, which should give interesting insights at a glance. It is an absolute POC, which has been created on the side in the last couple of days. First feedback has already been received and incorporated.  Overview The app is a single page application that does not have its own backend. Especially in the decentralized environment, in many cases there is no longer necessarily a need for a standalone backend. Of course, this is not true for all use cases, but especially in this case it was absolutely not necessary.  maker-delegates-overview2960×540 37.1 KB  As you can see in the overview, the application makes use of publicly available sources and links and aggregates them. The complete logic is executed within the application on the client.  maker-delegates-overview3960×540 62.8 KB  The user interface is very simple. It offers two main views: an overview of all delegates and a detailed view with the corresponding polls and execs. The delegate list contains various details about a delegate and an overview of the activity: participation in polls and support of executive votes. The order of delegates is derived from three factors:  First of all, the Exec score is compared. Here, the factor between supports and available execs is compared. If the value is equal, the average duration is compared. The next comparison is made according to the same principle as for Execs but on the basis of Votes. If the first two criteria do not lead to a clear result, the status is compared. Delegates with the status recognized are listed above delegates with the status shadow.  Feedback is of course very welcome! Have fun!
content.GPT-summary: The author explains a web application that displays statistics about Maker Delegates. The app is a proof of concept that aggregates publicly available sources and links. The user interface is simple and offers two main views: an overview of all delegates and a detailed view with corresponding polls and execs. The author welcomes feedback.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal

content.content: Super cool–thank you–looks fantastic! So, Executives don’t show up–not yet?–pretty sure @Planet_X @PaperImperium Monet and I have voted in the Exec.
Says 0 of 0. Probably hasn’t begun counting yet

Thank you! All Execs that are in the correct time frame depending on the Delegate are considered. Let’s take @Planet_X: According to metrics.md, the start date was on August 9, this date is used as the basis for considering Execs (and Polls) for @Planet_X.  The last supported Exec was on August 6 (so it is before the start date).  planet_x_tx1409×81 14.8 KB  The start dates are taken as a basis so that the dates can be compared more fairly. No delegate should be disadvantaged because the official start date was later than another delegate. This applies to delegates with the status recognized. The situation is different for delegates with the status shadow. Here the contract creation date is used as start date. Hope this helps!
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal

content.content: Says 0 of 0. Probably hasn’t begun counting yet  Exactly, all Execs and Polls are counted from the start date of the respective delegate.
This is a very slick proof of concept.
very cool! Thanks for making this.
monetsupply entry says: Start: January 1, 2030 all the other start dates look reasonable.

Yes that’s right, a bit far in the future  The start date in the metrics.md of @monet-supply  is set accordingly. As soon as the official start date is fixed and updated in metrics.md, it will be applied in the webapp as well.

content.content: I was using 2030 as a placeholder for ‘hasn’t been set yet’ Monet hadn’t done his ‘Meet Your Delegates’ Meeting at that point. I will update shortly and make sure Monet knows the date.
Quick update: we just pushed two new views into the application for viewing the voting and exec-support behavior of all candidates in an ugly table view. enjoy

Perhaps another useful metrics to display (for recognised) is forum activity (measured by one of the several metrics available from the Maker forum). It would also be nice to be able to sort delegates (e.g., by participation in polls etc). GREAT!
